questions.question: Study of internal structure of plants is called:
questions.explanation: Study of internal structure of plants is called anatomy. (NCERT Page 71)

questions.question: The three types of tissue systems in plants are:
questions.explanation: On the basis of structure and location, there are three types of tissue systems - epidermal, ground (fundamental) and vascular (conducting). (NCERT Page 71)

questions.question: The epidermal tissue system comprises:
options: Epidermal cells, stomata and epidermal appendages
questions.explanation: The epidermal tissue system forms the outermost covering and comprises epidermal cells, stomata and the epidermal appendages - trichomes and hairs. (NCERT Page 71)

questions.question: The epidermis is usually:
questions.explanation: Epidermis is usually single-layered. It is made up of elongated, compactly arranged cells which form a continuous layer. (NCERT Page 71-72)

questions.question: The waxy thick layer on the outside of epidermis is called:
questions.explanation: The outside of the epidermis is often covered with a waxy thick layer called the cuticle which prevents the loss of water. (NCERT Page 72)

questions.question: Cuticle is absent in:
questions.explanation: Cuticle is absent in roots. (NCERT Page 72)

questions.question: Stomata regulate:
questions.explanation: Stomata are structures present in the epidermis of leaves. Stomata regulate the process of transpiration and gaseous exchange. (NCERT Page 72)

questions.question: Each stoma is composed of two:
questions.explanation: Each stoma is composed of two bean-shaped cells known as guard cells which enclose stomatal pore. (NCERT Page 72)

questions.question: In grasses, the guard cells are:
questions.explanation: In grasses, the guard cells are dumb-bell shaped. (NCERT Page 72)

questions.question: The inner walls of guard cells (towards stomatal pore) are:
questions.explanation: The outer walls of guard cells (away from stomatal pore) are thin and the inner walls (towards the stomatal pore) are highly thickened. (NCERT Page 72)

questions.question: Guard cells possess:
questions.explanation: The guard cells possess chloroplasts and regulate the opening and closing of stomata. (NCERT Page 72)

questions.question: Specialized epidermal cells near guard cells are called:
questions.explanation: Sometimes, a few epidermal cells in the vicinity of guard cells become specialized in shape and size and are known as subsidiary cells. (NCERT Page 72)

questions.question: Stomatal apparatus includes:
options: Stomatal aperture, guard cells and subsidiary cells
questions.explanation: The stomatal aperture, guard cells and the surrounding subsidiary cells are together called stomatal apparatus. (NCERT Page 72)

questions.question: Root hairs are:
questions.explanation: The root hairs are unicellular elongations of the epidermal cells and help absorb water and minerals from the soil. (NCERT Page 72)

questions.question: Trichomes are epidermal hairs present on:
questions.explanation: On the stem the epidermal hairs are called trichomes. The trichomes in the shoot system are usually multicellular. (NCERT Page 72)

questions.question: Trichomes help in:
options: Preventing water loss due to transpiration
questions.explanation: The trichomes help in preventing water loss due to transpiration. (NCERT Page 72)

questions.question: Ground tissue consists of:
options: All tissues except epidermis and vascular bundles
questions.explanation: All tissues except epidermis and vascular bundles constitute the ground tissue. (NCERT Page 72)

questions.question: Ground tissue includes:
options: Simple tissues such as parenchyma, collenchyma and sclerenchyma
questions.explanation: Ground tissue consists of simple tissues such as parenchyma, collenchyma and sclerenchyma. (NCERT Page 72)

questions.question: In leaves, the ground tissue containing chloroplasts is called:
questions.explanation: In leaves, the ground tissue consists of thin-walled chloroplast containing cells and is called mesophyll. (NCERT Page 72)

questions.question: The vascular system consists of:
questions.explanation: The vascular system consists of complex tissues, the phloem and the xylem. (NCERT Page 73)

questions.question: In dicotyledonous stems, cambium is present:
questions.explanation: In dicotyledonous stems, cambium is present between phloem and xylem. (NCERT Page 73)

questions.question: Vascular bundles with cambium that can form secondary tissues are called:
questions.explanation: Vascular bundles with cambium possess the ability to form secondary xylem and phloem tissues, and hence are called open vascular bundles. (NCERT Page 73)

questions.question: In monocotyledons, vascular bundles are:
questions.explanation: In monocotyledons, vascular bundles have no cambium present in them. Hence, since they do not form secondary tissues they are referred to as closed. (NCERT Page 73)

questions.question: Radial arrangement of vascular bundles is found in:
questions.explanation: When xylem and phloem within a vascular bundle are arranged in an alternate manner along different radii, the arrangement is called radial such as in roots. (NCERT Page 73)

questions.question: In conjoint vascular bundles:
options: Xylem and phloem are on different radii
Xylem and phloem are on same radius
questions.explanation: In conjoint type of vascular bundles, the xylem and phloem are jointly situated along the same radius of vascular bundles. (NCERT Page 73)

questions.question: Conjoint vascular bundles are common in:
questions.explanation: Conjoint vascular bundles are common in stems and leaves. The conjoint vascular bundles usually have phloem located only on the outer side of xylem. (NCERT Page 73)

questions.question: The outermost layer of dicot root is called:
questions.explanation: In dicot root, the outermost layer is epiblema. Many of the cells of epiblema protrude in the form of unicellular root hairs. (NCERT Page 73)

questions.question: The cortex of dicot root consists of:
options: Several layers of thin-walled parenchyma cells
questions.explanation: The cortex consists of several layers of thin-walled parenchyma cells with intercellular spaces. (NCERT Page 73-74)

questions.question: The innermost layer of cortex in root is:
questions.explanation: The innermost layer of the cortex is called endodermis. It comprises a single layer of barrel-shaped cells without any intercellular spaces. (NCERT Page 74)

questions.question: The water-impermeable, waxy material deposited on endodermal cell walls is:
questions.explanation: The tangential as well as radial walls of the endodermal cells have a deposition of water-impermeable, waxy material suberin in the form of casparian strips. (NCERT Page 74)

questions.question: Casparian strips are found in:
questions.explanation: The walls of endodermal cells have a deposition of suberin in the form of casparian strips. (NCERT Page 74)

questions.question: Pericycle in roots is involved in:
options: Initiation of lateral roots and vascular cambium
questions.explanation: Next to endodermis lies pericycle. Initiation of lateral roots and vascular cambium during the secondary growth takes place in these cells. (NCERT Page 74)

questions.question: In dicot root, the number of xylem and phloem patches is usually:
questions.explanation: There are usually two to four xylem and phloem patches in dicot root. (NCERT Page 74)

questions.question: Parenchymatous cells between xylem and phloem in root are called:
questions.explanation: The parenchymatous cells which lie between the xylem and the phloem are called conjunctive tissue. (NCERT Page 74)

questions.question: All tissues on the inner side of endodermis constitute:
questions.explanation: All tissues on the innerside of the endodermis such as pericycle, vascular bundles and pith constitute the stele. (NCERT Page 74)

questions.question: In monocot root, the number of xylem bundles is usually:
questions.explanation: As compared to dicot root which have fewer xylem bundles, there are usually more than six (polyarch) xylem bundles in the monocot root. (NCERT Page 74)

questions.question: Pith in monocot root is:
questions.explanation: Pith is large and well developed in monocot root. (NCERT Page 74)

questions.question: Secondary growth in monocot roots:
questions.explanation: Monocotyledonous roots do not undergo any secondary growth. (NCERT Page 74)

questions.question: In dicot stem, the outermost layer is:
questions.explanation: The epidermis is the outermost protective layer of the dicot stem. (NCERT Page 74-75)

questions.question: The collenchymatous cells just below epidermis in dicot stem constitute:
questions.explanation: The outer hypodermis consists of a few layers of collenchymatous cells just below the epidermis, which provide mechanical strength to the young stem. (NCERT Page 75)

questions.question: The endodermis of dicot stem is also called:
questions.explanation: The cells of the endodermis are rich in starch grains and the layer is also referred to as the starch sheath. (NCERT Page 75)

questions.question: In dicot stem, pericycle is present as:
questions.explanation: Pericycle is present on the inner side of the endodermis and above the phloem in the form of semi-lunar patches of sclerenchyma. (NCERT Page 76)

questions.question: Medullary rays in dicot stem consist of:
questions.explanation: In between the vascular bundles there are a few layers of radially placed parenchymatous cells, which constitute medullary rays. (NCERT Page 76)

questions.question: In dicot stem, vascular bundles are arranged in:
questions.explanation: A large number of vascular bundles are arranged in a ring; the 'ring' arrangement of vascular bundles is a characteristic of dicot stem. (NCERT Page 76)

questions.question: Vascular bundles in dicot stem are:
questions.explanation: Each vascular bundle in dicot stem is conjoint, open, and with endarch protoxylem. (NCERT Page 76)

questions.question: The central portion of dicot stem is occupied by:
questions.explanation: A large number of rounded, parenchymatous cells with large intercellular spaces which occupy the central portion of the stem constitute the pith. (NCERT Page 76)

questions.question: Hypodermis in monocot stem is:
questions.explanation: The monocot stem has a sclerenchymatous hypodermis. (NCERT Page 76)

questions.question: In monocot stem, vascular bundles are:
questions.explanation: The monocot stem has a large number of scattered vascular bundles, each surrounded by a sclerenchymatous bundle sheath. (NCERT Page 76)

questions.question: Each vascular bundle in monocot stem is surrounded by:
questions.explanation: In monocot stem, vascular bundles are each surrounded by a sclerenchymatous bundle sheath. (NCERT Page 76)

questions.question: Vascular bundles in monocot stem are:
questions.explanation: Vascular bundles in monocot stem are conjoint and closed. (NCERT Page 76)

questions.question: In monocot stem, phloem parenchyma is:
questions.explanation: In monocot stem, the phloem parenchyma is absent, and water-containing cavities are present within the vascular bundles. (NCERT Page 76)

questions.question: Peripheral vascular bundles in monocot stem are generally:
questions.explanation: Peripheral vascular bundles are generally smaller than the centrally located ones. (NCERT Page 76)

questions.question: Dicotyledonous leaf is also called:
questions.explanation: Dicotyledonous leaf is also called dorsiventral leaf. (NCERT Page 76)

questions.question: The three main parts of dorsiventral leaf are:
questions.explanation: The vertical section of a dorsiventral leaf shows three main parts: epidermis, mesophyll and vascular system. (NCERT Page 76)

questions.question: In dicot leaf, the upper surface epidermis is called:
questions.explanation: The epidermis covers both the upper surface (adaxial epidermis) and lower surface (abaxial epidermis) of the leaf. (NCERT Page 76)

questions.question: In dorsiventral leaf, more stomata are present on:
questions.explanation: The abaxial epidermis generally bears more stomata than the adaxial epidermis. The latter may even lack stomata. (NCERT Page 76)

questions.question: The tissue between upper and lower epidermis of leaf is called:
questions.explanation: The tissue between the upper and the lower epidermis is called the mesophyll. (NCERT Page 76)

questions.question: Mesophyll carries out:
questions.explanation: Mesophyll, which possesses chloroplasts and carry out photosynthesis, is made up of parenchyma. (NCERT Page 76)

questions.question: The two types of mesophyll cells in dicot leaf are:
questions.explanation: Mesophyll has two types of cells - the palisade parenchyma and the spongy parenchyma. (NCERT Page 76)

questions.question: Palisade parenchyma is located:
questions.explanation: The adaxially placed palisade parenchyma is made up of elongated cells, which are arranged vertically and parallel to each other. (NCERT Page 76-77)

questions.question: Spongy parenchyma cells are:
options: Oval or round and loosely arranged
questions.explanation: The oval or round and loosely arranged spongy parenchyma is situated below the palisade cells and extends to the lower epidermis. (NCERT Page 77)

questions.question: Vascular bundles in leaf are surrounded by:
questions.explanation: The vascular bundles are surrounded by a layer of thick walled bundle sheath cells. (NCERT Page 77)

questions.question: Monocotyledonous leaf is also called:
questions.explanation: Monocotyledonous leaf is also called isobilateral leaf. (NCERT Page 77)

questions.question: In isobilateral leaf, stomata are present on:
questions.explanation: In an isobilateral leaf, the stomata are present on both the surfaces of the epidermis. (NCERT Page 77)

questions.question: In monocot leaf, mesophyll is:
options: Not differentiated into palisade and spongy
questions.explanation: In isobilateral leaf, the mesophyll is not differentiated into palisade and spongy parenchyma. (NCERT Page 77)

questions.question: Bulliform cells are found in:
questions.explanation: In grasses, certain adaxial epidermal cells along the veins modify themselves into large, empty, colourless cells called bulliform cells. (NCERT Page 77)

questions.question: Bulliform cells help in:
options: Rolling of leaves to minimize water loss
questions.explanation: When bulliform cells are flaccid due to water stress, they make the leaves curl inwards to minimise water loss. (NCERT Page 77)

questions.question: When bulliform cells are turgid:
questions.explanation: When the bulliform cells in the leaves have absorbed water and are turgid, the leaf surface is exposed. (NCERT Page 77)

questions.question: Which is NOT a characteristic of dicot root?
options: Pith is large and well developed
questions.explanation: In dicot root, the pith is small or inconspicuous. Large and well developed pith is characteristic of monocot root. (NCERT Page 74)

questions.question: Ring arrangement of vascular bundles is characteristic of:
questions.explanation: The 'ring' arrangement of vascular bundles is a characteristic of dicot stem. (NCERT Page 76)

questions.question: Scattered vascular bundles are characteristic of:
questions.explanation: The monocot stem has a large number of scattered vascular bundles. (NCERT Page 76)

questions.question: Which tissue provides mechanical strength to young dicot stem?
questions.explanation: The outer hypodermis consists of collenchymatous cells which provide mechanical strength to the young stem. (NCERT Page 75)

questions.question: Endarch protoxylem means:
questions.explanation: Endarch protoxylem means protoxylem lies towards the centre (pith) and metaxylem towards the periphery, as seen in dicot stem. (NCERT Page 76)

questions.question: Secondary growth occurs in:
questions.explanation: The secondary growth occurs in most of the dicotyledonous roots and stems. (NCERT Page 77)
